Simply amazing and amazingly simple, this rare historical gem hidden in plain sight offers more than an eye of the beholder catches. This truly stunning edifice is nothing short of an architectural feast, elaborate yet somewhat reserve in its style, a mixture of classic grandeur and noble modesty. Within its luxurious sales d'accueil and exquisite gold plated chambers one can sense a pulsating feeling of coming back in time. The ambience this tiny yet gracious hotel imparts upon a visitor is almost mystique, yet so authentic. As visitor, you are ushered into its historic legacy, almost untainted by the vicissitudes of time, countless wars, revolutions, tragedies and other destructive forces. Undoubtedly this is one of the sweetest, yet so unimposing indulgences of the Old Medieval Paris.

H√¥tel de Lauzun is a 17th-century h√¥tel particulier, or private mansion, located on the quai d'Anjou of the √Æle Saint-Louis in the 4th arrondissement of Paris, France. It is among the few parisians h√¥tels that retain their rich carved, painted, mirrored and gilded interiors from the time of Louis XIV.
Interesting but not fascinating. Amazing though that it belongs to the City of Paris.
Cool
great location

The cost of the visit is unaffordable, a real income for the beneficiaries. A delicious example of the Grand Si√®cle in the heart of √éle Saint Louis, at the time when precious jewels held salons and the H√¥tels du Marais were in decline.

Inside the Ile Saint Louis here is a jewel of the Grand Siecle, which has been preserved very well. Built in the 17th century. then it was purchased by the Duke of Lauzun, who married Anne Marie Louise Orleans. cousin of the Sun King. Who was repudiated by the court because of this marriage, but she had strong availability and created a little gem, then it was restored many years later... CHARLES BAUDELAIRE and T.Gautier and the painter Fernard Boisson lived here on the 2nd floor, they were also tenants. Boisson created the Club des Hashischins, where artists, scientists enjoyed hashish and cannabis, but connoted, the Bible. jams. not smoking...

Very nice private hotel  The Hotel de Lauzun is one of those Parisian mansions that are a real eye-catcher.  Even if for my part I admit to having been more dazzled by the H√¥tel de Beauharnais or that of La Pa√Øva, it is difficult to remain indifferent to the beauty of the painted ceilings and the richness of the decorations. The gold color is omnipresent, perhaps even a little too much.  This hotel housed the Haschischins club, hence the presence of Baudelaire in these places  The guided tour is obligatory to enter the place; In any case, it would be a shame to visit it without hearing its history.
A guided tour through the history of this extraordinary building, in terms of architecture and decoration, period moldings, gilding... For the record: Baudelaire lived there for a few years
Accessible only by guided tour, the H√¥tel de Lauzun is a unique jewel in Paris. A true jewel to discover absolutely!
A work from all angles! üé®üßë‚Äçüé®
H√¥tel de Lauzun purchased by the city of Paris. Private mansion with a long history. The wall decorations, the flowerbeds, the ceilings have remained as they are. To visit.

Also called h√¥tel Pimodan, Baudelaire lived here between October 1843 and September 1845 on the top floor. His friend Th√©ophile Gautier, a great writer and journalist, also lived here. "Do you know what the first thing I did when I arrived in Paris? Look for the √éle Saint-Louis, the Pimodan hotel... Shades of Baudelaire and Gautier! That has since changed a lot, of course, but I'm far from feeling at ease. literary exile. Omnivorous, I keep my relations with Latin America intact, to which I add French and English literature. From the answers given by Julio Cort√°zar to a questionnaire from the Quotidien de Paris, November 1974

A place where the great writers Dumas, Th√©ophile Gautier, Baudelaire gathered, tried various psychedelics, communicated, dreamed, walked... It is important for those who appreciate these writers, are familiar with their biography, their influence on world culture and significant contribution to the consciousness of people üåßÔ∏è üîÜüôèüèºüåê overall a beautiful romantic place in the heart of Paris

Impressive private mansion nestled on Ile Saint Louis. Its facade presents the sobriety of the period offset by the majestic height of each level. We will notice a console balcony as well as exceptional painted and gilded gutters with a carp head. Its vast lounges with distinguished ceiling height are covered in gilded woodwork and refined wall paintings. This building is accessible to the public during heritage days.

Beautiful facade and externally looks well maintained compared to other hotels on the island. Building which was built in 1657 a priori the Duke of Lauzun having been insolent with Madame de Montespan, Louis XIV sent it for 10 years to the fortress of Pignerol, it is not the same standing.

Magnificent place, we organized a scientific event there. Superb conference room and excellent projection equipment. Please note when working there: the constraints linked to the preservation of the place (no drinking, no opening windows, etc.) and the absence of staff specifically dedicated to the organization.
Magnificent, absolutely worth visiting...

The H√¥tel de Lauzun is the only private mansion on √éle Saint-Louis open to the public. After a brief overview of the exterior architecture, our steps will lead us to the sumptuous residence of the Duke of Lauzun, whose incredible adventures we will recall in the company of the terrible Miss de Montpensier.
I didn't go in but loved the cast iron dolphins on the downspouts. Here they represent dolphins which are magnificent and justify why we call this part of the descent "dolphins".
One of the best preserved mid-17th century hotels in the city. Exceptional decor Not open to the public but only to groups.

H√¥tel de Lauzun was built between 1650 and 1658 by Charles Gruyn des Bordes. Commissioner of provisions for the cavalry of Louis 14. The hotel was acquired in 1682 by the Count of Lauzun after his 10-year stay in the Pignerol prison (fortress between Brian√ßon and Turin) for insults to the king, he occupied it until upon his departure from France in 1685 after waiting for his return to grace.   He left to assist King James 2 of England in the Irish War. The hotel passed through the hands of several owners, the Marquis de Richelieu, Pierre Fran√ßois Ogier then Charles de La Vall√©e the Marquis de Pimodan.              In the 19th century, Baron and banker Pichon restored it. The City of Paris bought it then Pichon's grandson acquired it once again. It became a historic monument in 1906. The City of Paris bought it again. It is a magnificent private mansion which today houses works of art. There were illustrious tenants like Th√©ophile Gautier and Charles Baudelaire.
I only saw the exterior and the courtyard - garden in front of the building. It's already magnificent like this. The gargoyles are very beautiful.

A palace, the hotel de Lauzun, on the banks of the Seine, was once inhabited by nobles, common mortals anyway, after they died. Now it belongs to the Municipality of Paris and the researchers/university students who are... immortals are also enjoying it here and there.
It's wonderful. Richness of the 17th century decor.  What a beautiful mansion, so well preserved and restored
Sublime palace! Perhaps the most beautiful private mansion in the capital! Stunningly rich 17th century decorations. A must see!
Very beautiful, unexpected, worth the visit
Very beautiful mansion that you absolutely must discover. But for how long will this be possible????
It was a shame not to meet Baroness Kessler, but other than that it was very nice.
The hotel was very stylish and good, I enjoyed my stay here.
All the beauty of Saint Louis Island and its heritage Beautiful private hotel.
A fabulous visit to a splendid private mansion...

Beautiful example of architecture and interior decoration spanning 4 centuries of history
